content:
Viewport2DVisual3D Class

In this Article

Renders the 2-D children within the specified 3-D viewport bounds.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.Windows.Markup.ContentProperty("Visual")]
public sealed class Viewport2DVisual3D : System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Visual3D

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • DispatcherObject
  • DependencyObject
  • System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Visual3D

Remarks

Viewport2DVisual3D enables you to place interactive 2-D content on a 3-D object. Its counterpart is the Viewport3DVisual class, which is a 2-D visual with 3-D children.

Viewport2DVisual3D is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.

Properties

  • CacheMode

    Gets or sets a cached representation of the Viewport2DVisual3D.

    public System.Windows.Media.CacheMode CacheMode { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • CacheMode

      A CacheMode that holds a cached representation of the Viewport2DVisual3D.

    Remarks

    Set the CacheMode property when you need to increase performance for content that is time-consuming to render. For more information, see BitmapCache.

    The Viewport2DVisual3D class projects 3-D content into 2-D to size the 2-D content in the 3-D element correctly.

    Because caching always relies on the elementâ€™s size, instead of the transform applied to it, when you set the CacheMode property, initially your content may appear pixilated. This is because it is being upsampled to a much larger size than it was cached at. You can correct this situation by increasing the local size of your 2-D visual by setting the Height or Width properties. Also, you can increase the RenderAtScale on the CacheMode until the content reaches an acceptable level of clarity.

  • Geometry

    Gets or sets the 3-D geometry for this Viewport2DVisual3D.

    public System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Geometry3D Geometry { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Geometry3D

      The 3-D geometry for this Viewport2DVisual3D.

    Remarks

    Geometry is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.

    Example

    The following example shows how to place a button, a 2-D object, on a 3-D object: 

    <Viewport3D>
    <Viewport3D.Camera>
        <PerspectiveCamera Position="0, 0, 4"/>
    </Viewport3D.Camera>
    
    <!-- Button on 3D -->
    <Viewport2DVisual3D>
        <!-- Give the plane a slight rotation -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
            <RotateTransform3D>
                <RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
                    <AxisAngleRotation3D Angle="40" Axis="0, 1, 0" />
                </RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
            </RotateTransform3D>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
        
        <!-- The Geometry, Material, and Visual for the Viewport2DVisual3D -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>
            <MeshGeometry3D Positions="-1,1,0 -1,-1,0 1,-1,0 1,1,0"
                            TextureCoordinates="0,0 0,1 1,1 1,0" TriangleIndices="0 1 2 0 2 3"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>

        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>
            <DiffuseMaterial Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial="True" Brush="White"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>                               
        
        <Button>Hello, 3D</Button>
    </Viewport2DVisual3D>
    
    <!-- Lights -->
    <ModelVisual3D>
        <ModelVisual3D.Content>
            <DirectionalLight Color="#FFFFFFFF" Direction="0,0,-1"/>
        </ModelVisual3D.Content>
    </ModelVisual3D>
</Viewport3D>

    For the complete sample, see Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample.

  • Material

    Gets or sets the material that describes the appearance of the 3-D object.

    public System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Material Material { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Material

      The material for the 3-D object.

    Remarks

    You must set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial%2A> attached property on the material on which you wish to have the 2-D visual placed.

    Material is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.

    Example

    The following example shows how to specify the material where the 2-D visual (the button) should be placed by setting this property and also setting the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial%2A> attached property to true: 

    <Viewport3D>
    <Viewport3D.Camera>
        <PerspectiveCamera Position="0, 0, 4"/>
    </Viewport3D.Camera>
    
    <!-- Button on 3D -->
    <Viewport2DVisual3D>
        <!-- Give the plane a slight rotation -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
            <RotateTransform3D>
                <RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
                    <AxisAngleRotation3D Angle="40" Axis="0, 1, 0" />
                </RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
            </RotateTransform3D>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
        
        <!-- The Geometry, Material, and Visual for the Viewport2DVisual3D -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>
            <MeshGeometry3D Positions="-1,1,0 -1,-1,0 1,-1,0 1,1,0"
                            TextureCoordinates="0,0 0,1 1,1 1,0" TriangleIndices="0 1 2 0 2 3"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>

        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>
            <DiffuseMaterial Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial="True" Brush="White"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>                               
        
        <Button>Hello, 3D</Button>
    </Viewport2DVisual3D>
    
    <!-- Lights -->
    <ModelVisual3D>
        <ModelVisual3D.Content>
            <DirectionalLight Color="#FFFFFFFF" Direction="0,0,-1"/>
        </ModelVisual3D.Content>
    </ModelVisual3D>
</Viewport3D>

    For the complete sample, see Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample.

  • Visual

    Gets or sets the 2-D visual to be placed on the 3-D object.

    public System.Windows.Media.Visual Visual { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Visual

      The visual to be placed on the 3-D object.

    Remarks

    The visual is first applied to the VisualBrush, which is then used on the 3-D object.

    Visual is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.

    Example

    The following example shows how to place a button, a 2-D object, on a 3-D object: 

    <Viewport3D>
    <Viewport3D.Camera>
        <PerspectiveCamera Position="0, 0, 4"/>
    </Viewport3D.Camera>
    
    <!-- Button on 3D -->
    <Viewport2DVisual3D>
        <!-- Give the plane a slight rotation -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
            <RotateTransform3D>
                <RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
                    <AxisAngleRotation3D Angle="40" Axis="0, 1, 0" />
                </RotateTransform3D.Rotation>
            </RotateTransform3D>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Transform>
        
        <!-- The Geometry, Material, and Visual for the Viewport2DVisual3D -->
        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>
            <MeshGeometry3D Positions="-1,1,0 -1,-1,0 1,-1,0 1,1,0"
                            TextureCoordinates="0,0 0,1 1,1 1,0" TriangleIndices="0 1 2 0 2 3"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Geometry>

        <Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>
            <DiffuseMaterial Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial="True" Brush="White"/>
        </Viewport2DVisual3D.Material>                               
        
        <Button>Hello, 3D</Button>
    </Viewport2DVisual3D>
    
    <!-- Lights -->
    <ModelVisual3D>
        <ModelVisual3D.Content>
            <DirectionalLight Color="#FFFFFFFF" Direction="0,0,-1"/>
        </ModelVisual3D.Content>
    </ModelVisual3D>
</Viewport3D>

    For the complete sample, see Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample.

    Property Value

      To be added.
